Loss of EXO70A1 function disrupts the recruitment of other exocyst subunits to the plasma membrane in Arabidopsis root epidermal cells . Some known cargo proteins for plant exocystr complex-mediated trafficking include PIN auxin transporters, brassinosteroid receptor, brassinsinosteroids, cellulose synthase complexes and cellulose synases

Short-term ES2 treatment inhibits the transport of PIN-FORMED (PIN) family auxin transporter, PIN2, and the brassinosteroid receptor BRI1, to the plasma membrane . In mammalian cells, ES2 reduces the cell surface abundance of a membrane-anchored metalloproteinase MT2-MMP . In addition to the role of the ex
Heavy and light dimethyl-labeled peptides mixed after the labeled peptides were acidified with 20 µl of 10% formic acid and then fractionated by basic pH reverse-phase stage tips .

Peptides were separated on a 45 cm in-house packed column (360 µm OD × 75 µm ID) containing C18 resin (2.2 µm, 100Å, Michrom Bioresources, Auburn, CA, USA) with a 30 cm column heater (Analytical Sales and Services, Flanders, NJ, USA), set at 60°C

The mean fluorescence intensity of the GFP signal for each ROI was measured . The plasma membrane / cytoplasm ratio was calculated by subtracting the plasma membrane . The average PM fluorescence . intensity was normalized by adding the mean flu . intensity to the mean . fluorescenceintensity of the plasma . membrane membrane . region .

The Golgi/TGN protein, SYP41, was detected in the crude membrane fraction but not in the enriched plasma membrane fraction . We prepared four independent biological replicates of enriched plasma membranes for the mass spectrometry proteomics analysis .

We detected 3675 proteins from four independent replicate experiments . We compared our plasma membrane protein list with one generated from two-week-old liquid cultured Arabidopsis seedlings . We found 295 overlapping proteins, accounting for 95% of the proteins detected in Nelson et.’s experiments (309 proteins in total) We found 960 overlapping proteins .
The L/H value is the ratio of the abundance in ES2-treated samples divided by the abundance of protein in mock-treated samples .

The abundance of several proteins at the plasma membrane is reduced following ES2 treatment . The average PM fluorescence intensity was normalized by subtracting the mean fluorescenceintensity of the cytoplasmic background .

The abundance of some proteins that respond to cold and phosphate deficiency was significantly reduced in ES2-treated samples . Proteins involved in lignin metabolism were also reduced, as were proteins involved in brassinosteroid and auxin signaling .

DeepTMHMM predicted that 36 of the 145 proteins with reduced abundance contained signal peptides . The existence of a signal peptide in a small percentage of proteins indicates that plant exocyst complex mediates transport of proteins in both conventional and unconventional trafficking pathways .

The abundance of EXO70A1 was not affected by ES2 treatment . When all four faces of the plasma membrane were combined and averaged, there was a modest decrease in the abundance . This was not statistically significant .

Gene Ontology enrichment analysis of the biological function category . We found that this list of proteins is enriched in biological functions of COPII-coated vesicle cargo loading, mRNA catabolic process, negative regulation of translation, proton membrane transport, leaf senescence, ribonucleoprotein complex biogenesis and amide biosynthesis process .
The plant exocyst complex colocalizes with its cargo protein (Cellulose Synthase Complex or CSC) during the tethering process and then separates from the cargo after successful fusion .

The plasma membrane serves as a hub for cells to respond to environmental and growth cues . These studies further indicate that the vesicle trafficking machinery that facilitates the transport of these proteins is essential for plants .

BRI1 is a critical component of a plasma-membrane receptor for plant steroids . Annan1 and ANN2 function in post-phloem sugar transport in root tips to affect primary root growth .
The plant is the result of a study by Y. Zhang, C. Liu, A.-M. Emons and T. Emmons . Zhang and Emmons published in 2010 . Emmons' findings were published in The Plant Exocyst .
